container.heading: Administration of a Maintenance Injectable Medication

section.heading: Scope.
section.text: This chapter does not limit or otherwise affect the right of an individual to practice pharmacy or any other health occupation that the individual is authorized to practice.

para.text: In this chapter, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
Terms Defined.
“Authorized prescriber” means a practitioner licensed and authorized under Health Occupations Article, Annotated Code of Maryland, to prescribe prescription drugs.
“Board” means the Maryland Board of Pharmacy.
Maintenance Injectable Medication.
“Maintenance injectable medication” means a medication that:
Is administered by injection other than intravenously;
Except as authorized for a self-administered drug pursuant to Health Occupations Article, §12-509, Annotated Code of Maryland, is not a biological product; and
Treats a chronic need, condition, or disorder.
“Maintenance injectable medication” includes, but is not limited to, a medication for:
The treatment of a psychiatric disorder;
The treatment of a substance use disorder;
Contraception; and
Vitamins.
“Pharmacist” means an individual who practices pharmacy under Health Occupations Article, §12-101, Annotated Code of Maryland.
“Practicing pharmacy” has the meaning stated in Health Occupations Article, §12-101(x), Annotated Code of Maryland.
“Primary care practitioner” means a licensed health care practitioner who provides an individual’s primary care services and is the primary coordinator of health care services for the individual.

section.heading: Requirements to Administer a Maintenance Injectable Medication — Pharmacist’s Responsibilities.

para.text: Upon completion of all requirements established by the Board in this chapter, and after review of all relevant information, a pharmacist may administer a maintenance injectable medication.
In order to administer a maintenance injectable medication, a pharmacist shall:
Utilize and follow the Board-approved procedure set forth in Regulation .07 of this chapter to administer a maintenance injectable medication;
Refer a patient for additional care to the patient’s primary care practitioner or the authorized prescriber, if necessary;
Provide the patient and the authorized prescriber with a copy of the visit summary, including a written record of the maintenance injectable medication that was administered;
Document the encounter and maintain records pursuant to Regulation .05 of this chapter; and
Notify the authorized prescriber that the medication was administered to the specific patient and any relevant information about the patient’s condition.
A pharmacist shall:
Obtain written approval from the patient’s authorized prescriber prior to administering an initial dose of a maintenance injectable medication; and
Notify the patient of all fees that the patient is required to pay before administering a maintenance injectable medication.

Except as provided in §C of this regulation, a pharmacist shall successfully complete a Board-approved training program for the administration of injectable maintenance medications prior to administering injectable maintenance medications.
At a minimum, a Board-approved training program consists of the following elements:
Administration of a maintenance injectable medication;
Management of the patient populations served by a pharmacist;
Knowledge of the specific maintenance injectable medications that a pharmacist may administer; and
Current guidelines relating to the specific patient populations served by a pharmacist and the specific maintenance injectable medications that a pharmacist may administer, if applicable.
The training program requirement set forth in §A of this regulation is waived for a pharmacist who has undergone the training as part of a formal education program.

A pharmacy student in a Pharmacy Experiential Program or a registered pharmacy intern, who has successfully completed a Board-approved certification course under Health Occupations Article, §12-508, Annotated Code of Maryland, may administer a maintenance injectable medication under the direct supervision of a licensed pharmacist who meets the requirements set forth in Regulation .03 of this chapter.

A pharmacy that staffs a pharmacist that administers a maintenance injectable medication shall maintain the records of a minor patient, including the information listed in §B of this regulation, until the minor patient attains the age of majority plus 3 years or for 5 years after the record was made, whichever is later.

For a minimum of 5 years, except for records related to minors, a pharmacy that staffs a pharmacist that administers a maintenance injectable medication shall maintain documentation, in electronic or other form, including:
The type and dose of maintenance injectable medication administered;
The name, address, and date of birth of the patient;
The name of the pharmacist who administered the maintenance injectable medication;
The date that the maintenance injectable medication was administered;
A copy of the patient’s visit summary, including any pertinent details about the patient’s condition; and
The name and address of the authorized prescriber of the maintenance injectable medication.
A pharmacist who administers an injectable maintenance medication as an independent provider at a location that is not a pharmacy shall maintain records as required by §§A and B of this regulation.
A pharmacist that administers a maintenance injectable medication shall:
Obtain a paper or electronic consent form signed by the patient, or the patient’s legal guardian, that authorizes the pharmacist to administer the maintenance injectable medication;
Provide the patient, or the patient’s legal guardian, with a copy of the consent form for future reference upon request;

Provide the patient, or the patient’s legal guardian, and the authorized prescriber with a copy of the visit summary, including a written record of the maintenance injectable medication that was administered; and
Notify the patient of the need to attend any upcoming appointments the patient has scheduled with the prescriber for additional care.
The administering pharmacist shall:
Disclose their credentials on the consent form; and
Provide every patient with notification of the fee for service prior to administration.
Before a pharmacist administers a maintenance injectable medication, a pharmacist shall have and maintain a written procedure for any maintenance injectable medication that may be administered.
A pharmacist shall administer a maintenance injectable medication in accordance with the written procedure, including:
Recording and maintaining the prescription files in accordance with Regulation .05 of this chapter;
Reviewing and screening for the following:
Indications;
Precautions;
Contraindications; and
Allergies;
Reviewing the process for handling adverse reactions, including but not limited to:
Acute anaphylactic reactions; and
Other acute emergencies;
Following injection or administration procedures;
Advising the patient of post-administration procedures, including waiting requirements; and
Documenting and maintaining a maintenance injectable medication record, including:
Patient’s:
Name;
Date of birth;
Address;
Consent form;
Authorized prescriber; and
Administering pharmacist’s name and license number;
Administration:
Date;
Dose;
Site; and
Route;
Maintenance injectable medication:
Name, generic or brand;
Manufacturer;
Lot number; and
Expiration date;
Notification to the authorized prescriber that the patient received a specific maintenance injectable medication; and
Verification that the prescription is:
Not for the patient’s initial dose, if applicable; or
For the patient’s initial dose and the patient’s record contains documented approval from the authorized prescriber.
The pharmacist shall:
Sign and date the standard procedure at least annually;
Make the standard procedure available for inspection by the Board upon request; and
Review and update the standard procedure as necessary.
